Dear Harry:
TRUSTEES
Even though I’ve heard from you about the letter
to Seth Spalding I still haven't heard from him. Each
Douglas K. Baldwin
Wendell T. Burns
John E. Carroll
Forrest E. Conner
George D. Dayton II

Harold E. Wood
day I haunt the mailbox expecting some indication of
life on the part of the U.S. Office of Education.
Thanks very much for the phone number. John did
give it to me and I had every intention of calling
you. Unfortunately, all kinds of problems cropped up
and I never had the chance to use the number. Inci¬
dentally, I did not know that you were here on vaca¬
tion. I assumed it was a business-type trip. Had I
known, I would not have suggested our getting together.
I'm working on a progress report to be sent to
the Utilization Committee. As soon as I have it in
rough form I will send it to you. It is basically the
same as the letter to Spalding but in a much greater
detail.
Sorry to not have seen you.
Sincerely, ^
Clair R. Tettemer
/ Director of School
Programs & Research
CRT/gvc
